Forms

Checkboxes

  • Groups of checkboxes should be marked up using the fieldset and legend element. This helps someone using assistive technology to understand the question they're answering with the group of checkboxes. The fieldset is placed around the whole group and the legend contains the question.
  • Custom checkboxes are created by applying the .checkbox class to a <label> element. To remain accessible, place <input> with type="checkbox" inside the <label> element. The <input> is then visually hidden, and the styling is placed on a span with the .checkbox--faux class. The styling of the span changes based on whether the checkbox is selected or focused by using a pseudo-element. A second span with .form-element__label contains the label text.
  • When a single checkbox is required, <div class="checkbox"> should get <abbr class="required" title="required">*</abbr> added to the DOM, directly before the <input type="checkbox" />for visual indication that the checkbox is required.
  • When a checkbox group is required, the <fieldset> should receive the class .is-required. The <legend> should then get <abbr class="required" title="required">*</abbr> added to the DOM for visual indication that the checkbox group is required.
Focus Visible - Any keyboard operable user interface has a mode of operation where the keyboard focus indicator is visible.
Checkbox Group Label

Radio Buttons

  • Groups of radio buttons should be marked up using the fieldset and legend element. This helps someone using assistive technology to understand the question they're answering with the group of radio buttons. The fieldset is placed around the whole group and the legend contains the question.
  • Custom radio buttons are created by applying the .radio class to a <label> element. To remain accessible, place an <input> with type="radio" inside the
  • When a radio group is required, the <fieldset> should receive the class .is-required. The <legend> should then get <abbr class="required" title="required">*</abbr>added to the DOM for visual indication that the radio group is required.
Focus Visible - Any keyboard operable user interface has a mode of operation where the keyboard focus indicator is visible.

Select Lists

  • words
Focus Visible - Any keyboard operable user interface has a mode of operation where the keyboard focus indicator is visible.

Text Area

  • Inputs with errors should have aria-describedby to insure that the associated field level error message is read by assistive technology. If the error message has an id="my-error-message", then the input should have aria-describedby="my-error-message".
Info and Relationships - Information, structure, and relationships conveyed through presentation can be programmatically determined or are available in text.

Headings and Labels - Headings and labels describe topic or purpose.

Labels or Instructions - Labels or instructions are provided when content requires user input.

Text Inputs

  • Use labels and make the for="" and id="" values match. IDs must be unique on each page, only one label can be associated to each unique form element.
  • Keep it simple - screen readers do not support multiple labels that are linked to the same form element.
  • Inputs with errors should have aria-describedby to insure that the associated field level error message is read by assistive technology. If the error message has an id="my-error-message", then the input should have aria-describedby="my-error-message".
Guideline 3.2.2 - On Input - Changing the setting of any user interface component does not automatically cause a change of context unless the user has been advised of the behavior before using the component.
Guideline 3.3 - Input Assistance - Help users avoid and correct mistakes.
